description.narrative:
Project Description Project: Just <(>&<)> Sustainable Livelihoods (JSL): Organization and mobilization of fishers for their collective action Description: The partner; Pakistan Fisherfolk Forum proposed to extend Just and Sustainable Livelihoods (JSL) project forits third phase. Its first and pilot phase was implemented from September 2008 to August 2009 and the second phase was implemented from September 2009 to August 2012. Both of the phases were successfully completed with a number of achieved milestones. The abolition of the contract system through legislation is the most important one among them. The proposed project will focus to improve the livelihood of inland fishers through advocacy and lobbying in 6 districts of Punjab Province i.e. Muzaffargarh, Bakhar, Layyah, Lahore, Attock and Miyanwali and 8 districts of Sindh Province i.e. Karachi, Thatta, Badin, Jamshoro, Sanghar, Umerkot, Kashmore and Qambar-Shadadkot, however some marine fishing community of Karachi will also be addressed in order to mobilize and organize them so thatthey could play their proactive role in catalysing the struggle of inland fishers of the project area in getting the license systemimplemented. Moreover, one the main theme of the proposed project is the mobilization and organization of fishers. Th eoverall objective of the project is to bring positive policy level changes for the fishers and fisheries resources of Punjab while proper implementation of policies in Sindh through advocacy, lobbying and dialogue with the government and other stakeholders. More specifically the project aims (i) to organize and mobilize Fisherfolk (7,412 men <(>&<)> 3,668 women) of Sindh and Punjab and develop their capacities and ownership of PFF to make it stronger, more transparent and credible organization, (ii) to improve the access of 500 Fisherfolk to public inland water bodies and the protection and rehabilitation of 40 public inland waters for their sustainable livelihoods, and (iii) to do lobbying, networking and coordinating with civil society, media and other relevant stakeholders for the joint action to advocate rights of fisher community
Expected results of the project are; # Organization strengthened by 5% increase in the total membership having 30% women members with 25% women leadership at all levels # 500 new fishing licenses have been issued to genuine fishers by the end of project duration # The demarcation of 40 fresh water bodies is completed with adequate supply of fresh water and their environmental protection in Sindhby the end of project duration # Access of fishers to the resources increased by doingaway at least 25% of illegal encroachments on fresh waters of Sindh by the end of project duration # By the end of project duration, at least 25 members of provincial assembly of Punjab including 5 provincial ministers are sensitized about the abolition of contract system # A draft bill for the abolition of contract system in the Punjab is prepared by PFF in consultation with CSOs and other stakeholders and is submitted with parliamentarians # Legal support mechanism for fishers improved in Sindh as well as in Punjab.

participating-org.narrative:
The Pakistan Fisherfolk Forum (PFF) was set up in Karachi on May 5, 1998. The Forum was established in response to the need for effective lobby campaigns and programs for organising fisher communities in Pakistan. There should be a tangible and effectiveforum where communities can campaign for achieving their fundamental, socio-cultural and economic rights. PFF's objectives are: to mobilise and organise the fisher folk communities depending for their livelihoods on Pakistan's coast, rivers, lakes, reservoirs, ponds and other water bodies; to strengthen the organisation and management capacities and skills of the local CBOs of the fisher folk communities, and establish and strengthen PFU units in fishing villages and towns; to struggle for the livelihood rights of fishing communities, sustainability in fisheries livelihoods through advocacy, information dissemination, media campaigning and dialogue; to campaign for uprooting the causes and factors responsible for the depletion of coastal and inland fishing resources by advocating participatory approaches and management systems for the protection and conservation of fishing resources; to fight for the restoration and protection of human rights of the fishing communities of Pakistan, including the right to sustainable livelihoods, basic social services, the right to life and security as well as the right to social and political participation; to work for the social-economic advancement of the fishing communities and for improvement in education, health and livelihoods through participatory community development activities; to minimise disaster risks the communities face through relief and rehabilitation, and through participatory disaster mitigation and management activities in disaster prone areas; to work on improving the positing of vulnerable fisher folk; and finally to work on regional peace and co-operation for minimising regional hostilities affecting the fishing communities of Pakistan and India. Throughout the years PFF has undergone various changes: an increase in membership to 30,000 individuals and 130 units, an increase in the constituency, a more efficient organisational structure, a better targeting of priorities, staff development, and most importantly an integration of gender, where ithas succeeded in establishing 35 women's units. 18,000 out of 35,000 members are women and they participate at all levels in the organisation.
PFF is part of Oxfam International Consortium on DRR. This grant will help the partner to undertake urgentlyneeded preparatory humanitarian work. The initial preparatory work will help to engage with thedistrict government and to contribute from the inception of the response works.
